value: <l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0"><rs type="person" ref="../resources/annotations.xml#psn-espe" key="Spenser, Edmund">Spenser</rs> himeself heard the voice of the mummers. He</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">was present, it may be, at the pageant 
            <choice>
              <sic>wh.</sic>
              <corr>which</corr>
            </choice></l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">was acted before the <rs type="person" ref="../resources/annotations.xml#psn-eliz" key="Elizabeth I">Queen</rs> at <rs type="place" ref="../resources/annotations.xml#pla-keni" key="Kenilworth">Kenilworth.</rs></l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">He saw the players dressed in green.</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0"><del>He</del> For time had made the peasant, probably</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">the Earth in his own [guise?], a spectacle, a</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">figure from the past. The old superstitions</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">awed at their survival. But even while</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">the <del>old</del> <del>English was</del> the mummers were to act</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">not Robin hood, not <del><rs type="person" ref="../resources/annotations.xml#psn-gawa" key="Gawain">Gawain</rs></del> for the sophisticated</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">audience, but <rs type="literary-work" ref="../resources/annotations.xml#lit-faus" key="Faust">Faust</rs>, <rs type="literary-work" ref="../resources/annotations.xml#lit-tamb" key="Tamburlaine">Tamburlaine</rs>, the</l>
